column4: Can anyone tell me where the man pages are stored in the file system?
see /etc/manpath.config
you can also override it with $MANPATH
anything in that will be added to the man paths in the config file
try using ethtool
is that a seperate prog. in synaptic? or a default prog.?
i'm not sure, but i've got it installed so it's probably part of the base package set
thanks .. actually commandline startup is ethtool.. commandline only? or is there a gui available?
afaik it is command line only
k.. thanks!
i think you just need something like "ethool -s eth0 speed 100" though (look at the man pagE)
looking a man now.. I appriciate it.

am I right in thinking that if my Lan network & router are 100 that by reducing my one and only gigbit nic to 100 I should be able to help eliminate "data crashing" causing a slowdown of the internet connection?
your nic should autonegotitate with the rest of the network

it does, and is currently set that way, but I understand that it may autonegotiate with each send and receive.  If it always starts at 1000 then negotiates down to 100, that takes time..each time.  And although the time increment is small it can add up.
although i believe ifconfig will tell you what speed the device is actually using
i don't think that's how ethernet works, but i admit i'm not sure
but ethernet is supposed to be a broadcast protocol so it would make sense to only negotitate the speed once per every time a new device connects
except if the network (lan) was really busy it might do an "on the fly" negotiation
interesting article on speeding up tcp/ip connections.. http://www.acc.umu.se/~maswan/linux-netperf.txt
yeah, i took a networking/sockets programming class about a year ago and learned all about that stuff, it's really pretty interesting
an actual education! :) wow!  I'm just a 47 yr old hack.. but I like this stuff.
